That makes sense. I just don't think I've ever met anyone from Idaho who wasn't a potatoe farmer.

Idaho is renowned for its breathtaking scenery, superb fishing, and famous spuds (or Famous Potatoes, as they're affectionately known). However, some individuals within the state have a penchant for seeking harm for OR-7 and his other OR and non-OR companions.
While I cannot say I've ever heard of Idaho being recognized for anything other than its potato output, the state does boast a multitude of potato farms due to the sheer abundance of spuds grown within its borders. It's not uncommon to encounter potato farmers residing in the area.
It's possible that you haven't encountered individuals from Idaho often, as they tend to be rather elusive. One might say they're as rare as a potato with six eyes.
If you haven't experienced living in Idaho long enough, you may not be familiar with the prevalence of potato enthusiasts in everyday life. They're as common as mushrooms after a rain shower. Valencia put a great fight but ultimately fell in the third place game of the Oaks Christian tournament.
Lonnie Jackson scored 24 points but it wasnt enough in a 66-58 overtime setback against Sacramento.
The Vikings (8
continuation:
-5) trailed by as many as 10 points in the first half, but rallied to tie the game at 44-44 with 2:45 left in regulation.
Sacramento then went on a 9-0 run to open up a six-point lead and never looked back.
Jackson was held scoreless in the second half, but still managed to hit four 3-pointers.

input:
The United Nations has restarted its process for setting rules on "responsible state behaviour in cyberspace" with two separate forums, and Australia intends to continue being a key player.
On Friday, Australia's Ambassador for Cyber Affairs Dr Tobias Feakin
continuation:
announced that the Australian government had been invited to attend the first forum, which will be held in Geneva later this month.
The second forum will be hosted by the UN Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA) in New York, and will take place in October.
Dr Feakin said it was important for Australia to play an active role at both forums.
"Cybersecurity is one of our most important national security issues," he said.
"We're very pleased that we've been invited to participate in these forums."
Australia's cyber-security minister, Paul Fletcher, said the country was committed to working with the international community to ensure that all countries were able to protect their citizens from online threats.
"It is critical that all countries have access to the tools they need to protect their citizens," Mr Fletcher said in a statement.
"We are proud to be part of this initiative and look forward to contributing to the discussion."
In March, Australia became the first country to sign up to the UN Global Compact on Responsible State Behaviour in Cyberspace, which aims to create a global framework for responsible state behaviour in cyberspace.
Under the agreement, states commit to upholding human
paraphrase:
The United Nations has reinitiated its process for setting guidelines on "responsible state actions in cyberspace" with two separate forums, and Australia intends to continue playing a significant role.
On Friday, Australia's Ambassador for Cyber Affairs, Dr. Tobias Feakin, announced that the Australian government had been invited to attend the first forum, which will take place in Geneva later this month. The second forum will be hosted by the UN Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA) in New York and is scheduled to take place in October.
Dr. Feakin emphasized the importance of Australia's active participation in both forums, emphasizing that "cybersecurity is one of our most critical national security issues."
Australia's Cybersecurity Minister, Paul Fletcher, expressed the country's commitment to collaborating with the international community to ensure that all nations can protect their citizens from online threats. "It is essential that all countries have access to the tools they need to safeguard their citizens," Mr. Fletcher said in a statement. "We are proud to be part of this initiative and look forward to contributing to the discussion."
In March, Australia became the first country to sign up to the UN Global Compact on Responsible State Behavior in Cyberspace, which aims to establish a global framework for responsible state actions in cyberspace. Under the agreement, states commit to upholding human rights and promoting an open, free, and secure internet.

input:
During a day of events designed to raise the profile of his agenda for education, President Clinton last week urged parents and teachers to embrace a "whole ethic'' of lifelong learning to insure the nation's continued economic productivity.
"The fact of the
continuation:
matter is that if we don't keep up with the pace of change in our economy,'' he said, ''we will not be able to compete.''
In a speech at the National Press Club on Thursday, Mr. Clinton also called for an overhaul of America's high-school system, which he said was failing to prepare young people for the 21st-century job market.
"We need to make sure that every kid who wants to go to college can,'' he said.
Mr. Clinton has made education a central theme of his second term. He has proposed a $1.5 trillion increase in federal spending over the next decade on K-12 schools, higher education and community colleges.
His plan calls for raising the federal minimum wage from its current level of $7.25 an hour to $9.50 an hour by 2010. The proposal would also create a national paid family leave program and require all employers with 50 or more workers to offer 12 weeks of paid parental leave.
Mr. Clinton's proposals have been met with strong opposition from some Republicans, who argue that they are too expensive and could drive up the cost of consumer goods and services.
Mr. Clinton's remarks came during a daylong series of events
paraphrase:
To ensure the nation's continued economic success, President Clinton emphasized the importance of a lifelong learning ethos during a series of events aimed at boosting his education agenda. He stressed that failure to keep pace with the rapid changes in the economy could lead to a lack of competitiveness.
In a speech at the National Press Club, the President called for an overhaul of the high school system, which he believes is not adequately preparing young people for the job market of the 21st century. He also emphasized the need to make higher education more accessible, proposing a $1.5 trillion increase in federal spending over the next decade to improve K-12 schools, higher education, and community colleges.
Mr. Clinton's plan also includes a minimum wage increase to $9.50 per hour by 2010, as well as the creation of a national paid family leave program and a requirement for all employers with 50 or more workers to offer 12 weeks of paid parental leave. While some Republicans have criticized these proposals as too costly, the President remains committed to investing in the nation's future through education.

Following the Australian government citing a lack of separation of edge and core in 5G, Huawei has demonstrated what it says is full isolation of each network component in New Zealand on a trial network with Spark.
Huawei has revealed a 5G trial network
continuation:
in New Zealand that it claims to be fully isolated from the rest of the network.
The company's chief technology officer (CTO) Ren Zhengfei made the claim during a keynote speech at the Mobile World Congress (MWC) in Barcelona, Spain on Tuesday.
"We have been working on this for more than two years," he said. "I can say we are 100 per cent isolated from the rest of the network."
Zhengfei also claimed that the company's 5G base stations will be able to operate in extreme weather conditions, such as rain, snow or hail.
Advertisement
"It's not just about the radio frequency [RF] signal, it's also about the power supply," Zhengfei said. "When you look at the power supply, you can't see it, but it's very important."
He added: "You don't need to worry about the temperature, you don't need to worry about the humidity, you don't need to worry about the rain, you don't need to worry about the hail. It's all under control."
Huawei's CTO Ren Zhengfei. Photo / Supplied
New Zealand's National Cyber Security Centre (NCSC
paraphrase:
Huawei has demonstrated its ability to isolate individual network components in a trial network in New Zealand, according to the company's chief technology officer (CTO) Ren Zhengfei. Speaking at the Mobile World Congress (MWC) in Barcelona, Spain, Zhengfei claimed that the company's 5G base stations are fully isolated from the rest of the network, a move aimed at addressing concerns raised by the Australian government about the lack of separation of edge and core in 5G.
Zhengfei emphasized that the isolation is not limited to the radio frequency (RF) signal, but also includes the power supply, which is crucial for the base stations' operation. He assured that the company has taken measures to ensure the base stations can operate in extreme weather conditions, such as rain, snow, or hail.
New Zealand's National Cyber Security Centre (NCSC) has been working closely with Huawei on the trial network, according to Zhengfei. The NCSC is responsible for ensuring the country's cybersecurity and protecting critical infrastructure from potential threats.
Overall, Huawei's demonstration of full isolation of network components in New Zealand highlights the company's commitment to addressing security concerns in 5G technology.

input: Processor IP vendor ARM made the case yesterday afternoon that its processor IP is finding its way into more and more mobile devices. Certainly ARM based devicesincluding processors from companies such as Apple, Marvell, MediaTek, Nvidia, Qualcomm, Samsung
continuation:
, and Texas Instrumentshave been in use for some time, but ARMs presence has only increased over the last few years.

ARM CEO Simon Segars said during a keynote address at the Mobile World Congress (MWC) in Barcelona, Spain that the company now has more than 100 licensees of its intellectual property (IP). In addition, he noted that the number of Android-based products using ARMs technology continues to grow.

Weve seen a lot of growth in the last 12 months, Segars said. I think its safe to say that we have more than 100 licensees of our intellectual property today, and that number is growing every single day.

Segars also pointed out that ARMs licensing revenue has doubled since 2012, and that the companys licensing business now accounts for about 20 percent of its total revenues. He added that the companys licensing business is expected to reach $3 billion this year, up from $1.5 billion in 2013.

Its an important part of our business, Segars said.
paraphrase:
ARM, a leading provider of processor IP, has witnessed a significant increase in the adoption of its technology in mobile devices. According to CEO Simon Segars, the company has over 100 licensees of its intellectual property, with the number continuing to grow daily. He also noted that the number of Android-based products using ARM's technology is on the rise.
Segars highlighted the impressive growth of ARM's licensing revenue, which has doubled since 2012, accounting for approximately 20 percent of the company's total revenues. He expects the licensing business to reach $3 billion this year, up from $1.5 billion in 2013.
Segars emphasized the importance of the licensing business to ARM's overall operations, underscoring the company's commitment to this area.

input:
Nigeria remains deeply divided over a ban imposed last month on television stations showing so-called "miracles".
Programmes showing miracles have disappeared from screens in compliance with an edict from the Nigeria's National Broadcasting Commission, which took effect from
continuation:
January 1.
The commission said it had received complaints from viewers who were offended by such programmes.
But critics say the move is part of a wider campaign to stifle freedom of expression in Africa's most populous nation.
"This is a government that has no respect for the rule of law," said Oby Ezekwesili, a former minister of education and current vice-president of the opposition Peoples Democratic Party (PDP).
Ezekwesili was one of the signatories of a letter to President Muhammadu Buhari earlier this year, urging him to reverse the ban.
"We are living in a country where you can be arrested for criticising the government," she told the Thomson Reuters Foundation by phone from Lagos.
"It is very clear that they don't want to hear anything negative about them."
Buhari's spokesman, Garba Shehu, did not immediately respond to requests for comment.
In a statement on its website, the NCC said the ban was aimed at promoting religious tolerance and unity.
"The Commission wishes to state categorically that it does not intend to restrict any form of free speech or expression as enshrined in our constitution," it said.
"
paraphrase:
Nigeria's media landscape has been marred by a recent controversy surrounding the ban on television stations airing so-called "miracles". In compliance with a directive from the National Broadcasting Commission (NBC), programs displaying these supernatural occurrences have been removed from screens.
The NBC cited complaints from viewers offended by the content, but critics argue that the move is part of a larger effort to suppress free expression in the country. According to Oby Ezekwesili, a former education minister and current vice-president of the opposition Peoples Democratic Party (PDP), "This is a government that has no respect for the rule of law."
Ezekwesili was one of several signatories of a letter to President Muhammadu Buhari earlier this year, urging him to reverse the ban. She expressed concern that in a country where criticism of the government can lead to arrest, "We are living in a country where you can be arrested for criticising the government."
Buhari's spokesman, Garba Shehu, did not respond to requests for comment. In a statement on its website, the NBC defended the ban, stating that it aimed to promote religious tolerance and unity, while emphasizing its commitment to free speech and expression as enshrined in the constitution.
However, the debate over the ban highlights ongoing challenges to freedom of expression in Nigeria, with some critics arguing that the government is increasingly curtailing dissenting voices.

input:
An Illinois man who purchased a handgun and more than 100 rounds of ammunition in Marion, Iowa, was sentenced to more than three years in prison yesterday in federal court in Cedar Rapids.
Montarrance Wilson, age 27, from Chicago, Illinois,
continuation:
pleaded guilty to one count of unlawful possession of a firearm by a convicted felon. According to the plea agreement, Wilson admitted that he possessed an unregistered Smith & Wesson M&P Shield 9mm semiautomatic pistol on July 1, 2016, at his home in Chicago. Wilson also admitted that he had more than 100 rounds of.40-caliber ammunition in his vehicle when he was pulled over for speeding on Interstate 80 in Marion, Iowa, on June 28, 2016.
U.S. District Judge Robert E. Chambers imposed a sentence of 18 months imprisonment followed by three years supervised release. The judge also ordered Wilson to pay a $1,000 fine.
Assistant U.S. Attorney John R. Hulshof prosecuted the case.
This case is part of Project Safe Neighborhoods (PSN), a program bringing together all levels of law enforcement and the communities they serve to reduce violent crime and make our neighborhoods safer for everyone. In fiscal year 2017, PSN involved more than 800 law enforcement agencies in 37 states and Washington, D.C., with more than 3,000 arrests.
The Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives (ATF) investigated this case.
paraphrase: A man from Illinois was sentenced to over three years in federal prison after pleading guilty to possessing a firearm as a convicted felon. The man, Montarrance Wilson, 27, from Chicago, purchased a handgun and over 100 rounds of ammunition in Marion, Iowa, in July 2016. He was pulled over for speeding on Interstate 80 in Marion the same day and was found to have the weapon and ammunition in his vehicle. U.S. District Judge Robert E. Chambers imposed a sentence of 18 months imprisonment followed by three years supervised release, and ordered Wilson to pay a $1,000 fine. This case is part of Project Safe Neighborhoods, a program aimed at reducing violent crime and making communities safer, which involved over 800 law enforcement agencies in 37 states and Washington D.C. in fiscal year 2017, resulting in over 3,000 arrests. The Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives investigated the case.

input:
Education or Indoctrination in Texas?
The news from the nation's most influential state board of education is another reminder of the difficulty of creating a curriculum that passes muster with all stakeholders. In early March, the Texas board released its social studies standards
continuation:
for the 2020-21 school year. The standards are based on the Common Core State Standards (CCSS) developed by the U.S. Department of Education.
The CCSS were adopted by the states in 2010 and have been updated every two years since then to reflect changes in federal policy and state law. For instance, in 2018, the Trump administration withdrew federal funding for states that did not adopt the Common Core standards.
Texas was one of those states that opted out of the Common Core, but it has continued to use them as a framework for its social studies curriculum. As a result, many teachers and parents are concerned about how the standards will be implemented in their classrooms.
In response to these concerns, Gov. Greg Abbott recently signed into law House Bill 3, which prohibits local governments from requiring students to take any foreign language other than English as a second language (ESL). It also prohibits local governments from requiring students to take any foreign language other than English as a first language (EFL), including Spanish, Mandarin, Cantonese, Korean, and Tagalog. HB 3 does not apply to charter schools, public universities, or private institutions of higher education.
"This bill is an important step toward ensuring that Texans
paraphrase:
The debate in Texas surrounding the balance between education and indoctrination has been reignited with the recent release of the state's social studies standards for the 2020-21 school year. The standards, based on the Common Core State Standards (CCSS) developed by the US Department of Education, have been met with concerns from teachers and parents alike. While Texas opted out of the Common Core, it has continued to use them as a framework for its social studies curriculum, leading to questions about how the standards will be implemented in the classroom.
In an effort to address these concerns, Governor Greg Abbott recently signed House Bill 3 into law, which prohibits local governments from requiring students to take any foreign language other than English as a second language (ESL) or English as a first language (EFL), including Spanish, Mandarin, Cantonese, Korean, and Tagalog. However, this law does not apply to charter schools, public universities, or private institutions of higher education.
Despite these efforts, the question of whether education in Texas is more accurately described as "education" or "indoctrination" remains a topic of debate. While some argue that the standards and laws passed in Texas are essential for ensuring a well-rounded education, others contend that they infringe upon students' rights to cultural understanding and diversity. As the debate continues, it is clear that the issue of education and indoctrination in Texas is complex and multifaceted, and that there is no easy answer.

Should it be business as usual and a comfortable position of passivity, or should it answer, with action, the Palestinian call for solidarity and support?
At their base, these are the questions fuelling recent debates about the department of international relations'
continuation:
(DIR) role in Palestine.
The DIR has been accused by some of being too pro-Israel, while others have questioned its commitment to democracy and human rights.
But what is clear is that the DIR has an important role to play in promoting peace and stability in the Middle East and beyond.
In this context, it is important to look back at the DIR's history and consider how it has evolved over the last 50 years.

paraphrase:
In light of the recent debates surrounding the department of international relations' (DIR) role in Palestine, it is crucial to address the questions at the core of these discussions. Should the DIR maintain a business-as-usual approach, characterized by a comfortable position of passivity, or should it respond with action to the Palestinian call for solidarity and support?
The DIR's history and evolution over the last 50 years are particularly relevant in this context. By examining how the DIR has addressed conflicts in the Middle East and beyond, we can better understand its potential to promote peace and stability in the region.
The original article published on The Conversation raises important questions about the DIR's pro-Israel leanings and its commitment to democracy and human rights. While the article highlights the importance of looking back at the DIR's history to inform its future actions, it also underscores the need for the DIR to take a proactive stance in supporting the Palestinian people.
Ultimately, the decision to answer the Palestinian call for solidarity and support is a complex one that requires careful consideration of the DIR's role and responsibilities. By engaging in thoughtful and informed dialogue, we can work towards finding a solution that promotes peace, stability, and human rights in the Middle East and beyond.

A certain politician recently lost their very high-profile, very powerful job. While this was not a surprise to other people, they say it was a surprise to them.
They also say that what happened was unfair and uncalled for.
Despite
continuation:
the fact that they had done nothing wrong, they were fired from their position as a result of the actions of someone else.
This is not the first time such an incident has occurred.
In the past, politicians have been fired from their positions for similar reasons.
For example, former President George W. Bushs Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice was fired from her position after she refused to endorse his reelection bid in 2004.
Former President Barack Obamas Attorney General Eric Holder was also fired from his position after he refused to defend the Affordable Care Act (Obamacare) in front of the U.S. Supreme Court in 2013.
President Donald Trumps former White House Chief Strategist Steve Bannon was fired from his position as Executive Chairman of Breitbart News in 2017 after he refused to back Trumps presidential campaign in 2016.
So why do politicians lose their jobs?
There are a number of possible reasons, but one of the most common ones is that they fail to live up to the expectations set by those who elected them into office.
Some of these expectations may be unrealistic, while others may not be realistic at all.
Here are some examples:
1. Expectations
paraphrase: A prominent political figure recently lost their high-profile position, which came as a surprise to some but not to others. They have described the situation as unfair and unjustified, despite having done nothing wrong. This incident is not an isolated case, as similar scenarios have played out in the past. For instance, former President George W. Bush's Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice was fired after refusing to endorse his reelection bid in 2004, while former President Barack Obama's Attorney General Eric Holder was let go after he refused to defend the Affordable Care Act (Obamacare) in front of the Supreme Court in 2013. President Donald Trump's former White House Chief Strategist Steve Bannon was also fired from his position as Executive Chairman of Breitbart News in 2017 after he failed to back Trump's presidential campaign in 2016. The reasons for these firings can vary, but one of the most common is failing to meet the expectations of those who elected them. These expectations may be unrealistic or not realistic at all, and they can lead to political fallout for those involved.

input: The race for the Republican and Democratic nominations for president continue this week, as candidates face a crucial election in Michigan. Following the water crisis in Flint and Detroits bankruptcy, voters could be looking for a non-establishment candidate  which would be
continuation:
good news for Sen. Bernie Sanders (I-Vt.) and former Secretary of Housing and Urban Development Julin Castro (D).

But there are other signs that the race is tightening. A new NBC News/Wall Street Journal poll released on Tuesday found Sanders leading Donald Trump among likely Michigan voters by just one point, 49 percent to 48 percent. Thats a significant drop from last month, when Sanders was ahead by six points.

Sanderss lead comes despite the fact that he hasnt held a public event in Michigan since September. The Vermont senator has spent much of the campaign focused on his home state of New Hampshire, where polls show him trailing both Hillary Clinton and Jeb Bush.

Meanwhile, Trumps support among Michigan voters has remained steady over the past few months. He remains popular with white working-class voters, who make up more than two-thirds of the states electorate. And he still enjoys strong support among African-Americans, who account for nearly half of the states Democratic primary voters.

Trumps support among white working-class voters is particularly noteworthy because it suggests that he may have difficulty reaching out to black voters
paraphrase:
The presidential nomination race for the Republican and Democratic parties heats up this week in Michigan, as candidates vie for a critical election. Bernie Sanders (I-Vt.) and former Secretary of Housing and Urban Development Julian Castro (D).
However, new polling data suggests a tightening of the race. According to an NBC News/Wall Street Journal poll released Tuesday, Sanders leads Donald Trump among likely Michigan voters by a slim margin of 49% to 48%. This represents a significant decrease from last month, when Sanders held a six-point lead.
Sanders' lead can be attributed to his strong performance among white working-class voters, despite the fact that he has largely focused his campaign efforts on New Hampshire. On the other hand, Trump has maintained steady support among Michigan voters, particularly among white working-class voters, who make up the majority of the state's electorate. Additionally, he continues to enjoy strong backing from African-American voters, who account for nearly half of the Democratic primary electorate.
Trump's ability to appeal to both white working-class and African-American voters could be a challenge for him in the general election.

input: World Sake Day or "Nihonshu no Hi" is a significant day on the Japanese calendar with celebrations held annually on 1 October. This date is considered "New Year's Day" for sake because it marks the first day of the sake
paraphrase:
Japanese Culture Celebrates 'Sake Day' on October 1st
Japanese people celebrate 'Sake Day' on October 1st, which marks the beginning of the sake harvest season. The term 'Sake' originates from the kanji characters  (shi) meaning 'name' and (noi) meaning 'flavor'. The word 'nihonshu' is derived from the kanji characters (noi) and (shu) meaning 'flavor'.
In Japanese culture, 'Sake' is not just a drink, but a symbol of tradition, culture, and social gatherings. It is brewed from fermented rice and is a crucial part of Japanese hospitality and ceremonies. The sake harvest season typically lasts from mid-September to mid-October, making October 1st an essential date in the Japanese calendar.
The word 'sake' has a rich history, with its origins dating back to the 7th century. The term is believed to have originated from the kanji characters  (shi) and (noi), which together mean 'name' and 'flavor'. Over time, the term evolved into 'nihonshu,' which translates to 'Japanese flavor.'
In conclusion, 'Sake Day' is an essential date in Japan, marking the beginning of the sake harvest season and symbolizing the country's rich cultural heritage.

I wanted to do something different, Jean says. I was inspired by fairy tales, but I wanted it to be a little bit more modern and contemporary.

It was a dream come true for me, Jean says. I had worked with

Inspired by childrens books and fairy tales, the collection, titled Fairyland, featured whimsical and modern designs.

input:
The seven-day plan for getting your home and yard ready for summer.
On the HouseMitch KuffaGuest columnist FHA and private home housing inspector and licensed builder Mitchell Kuffa, of St. Clair, Wednesday April 14,
continuation:
2021, talks about how to get your home and yard ready for summer. (Photo: Robert Scheer/IndyStar)Buy Photo
I'm a real estate agent who specializes in single-family homes. I've been doing this for more than 30 years, and I can tell you that it's never been more important to make sure your house is ready for summer.
If you don't take care of these things now, you'll end up having to spend a lot of money on repairs later down the road.
Here are some things you need to do before the weather gets too hot.
1. Clean out the gutters and downspouts.
Gutters and downspouts should be cleaned out at least once a year. If they're clogged with leaves or other debris, you could have a problem with water seeping through the roof into your home.
2. Remove all debris from around your home.
Debris such as tree limbs and branches can cause damage to your siding if they're not properly removed. It's also a good idea to remove any large rocks or boulders that might fall onto your roof.
3. Make sure your windows are clean and free of dirt and grime
paraphrase:
Here are some tips to help you prepare your home and yard for the summer season:
As a seasoned real estate agent with over 30 years of experience, I can't stress enough the importance of getting your home ready for the warmer months. Neglecting maintenance tasks now can lead to costly repairs later on.
To start, make sure to clean out your gutters and downspouts at least once a year. Clogged gutters can cause water to seep through your roof and into your home, leading to potential damage.
Next, remove any debris from around your property, including tree limbs, branches, and large rocks or boulders that could fall onto your roof. A clean and debris-free area around your home will help prevent damage and keep your siding in good condition.
Finally, give your windows a thorough cleaning to remove any dirt or grime that may have accumulated over the winter months. Clean windows will not only improve the appearance of your home but also help regulate temperature and reduce energy costs.
By taking these simple steps, you'll be well on your way to a summer-ready home and yard. Remember, a little maintenance now can go a long way in preventing costly repairs down the line.

The 46-year-old father-of-two was found dead at Elsternwick Park in Brighton on Saturday

A post mortem will take place to determine the exact cause of death.
Hester was best known as one of the founding members of Australian rock band Crowded House, which went on to become one of the biggest bands in the world.
He is survived by his wife and two daughters.
"We are deeply saddened to learn of the passing of our beloved Paul," the band said in a statement. "Our thoughts and prayers go out to his family, friends and fans during this very difficult time."
Crowded House released their debut album 'Tales from Topographic Oceans' in 1983 and have sold more than 30 million albums worldwide.
They won four Grammy Awards, including Best Alternative Music Album for 'Tales from Topographic Oceans' in 1994.
Hester joined the band in 1984 and remained with them until 1997 when he left to form his own solo career.

continuation:

I would like to thank everyone involved for their hard work and dedication

According to the source, "It's going to happen, it's just a matter of when."

input:
Friends and supporters of a Tamil family, who are facing deportation, have marched through the rain to Peter Dutton's Brisbane office.
Singing The Seekers hit I am, you are, we are Australian, the protesters first rallied at a crowd
continuation:
-funding page set up for the family.
The campaign has so far raised more than $30,000, which will be used to help pay for their legal fees if they are sent back to Sri Lanka, where they were born.
Mr Dutton said on Tuesday that he had "no intention" of deporting the family.
He told Sky News: "I don't think it's appropriate to send them back to Sri Lanka."
But his comments drew criticism from Labor MP Kristina Keneally, who accused him of being "out of touch with reality".
"This is not just about one family, this is about thousands of families in Australia," she told reporters outside Mr Dutton's office.
"We've got a Prime Minister who is out of touch with reality when it comes to refugees and asylum seekers.
"It's time for him to get off his high horse and start acting like a Prime Minister."
Ms Keneally said she was "very concerned" about the family's fate.
"They have been here for over 20 years," she said.
"Their children have grown up here. Their grandchildren are going to grow up here.
"They are part of our community.
paraphrase: A group of supporters and friends of a Tamil family, who are at risk of deportation, gathered outside Peter Dutton's Brisbane office to protest. Singing The Seekers' song "I Am, You Are, We Are Australian," the protesters first rallied at a crowdfunding page set up to help the family with legal fees. So far, the campaign has raised over $30,000. Dutton previously stated he had no intention of deporting the family, but his comments were met with criticism from Labor MP Kristina Keneally, who accused him of being out of touch with reality. Keneally expressed concern for the family's fate, noting that they have been in Australia for over 20 years and have children and grandchildren who are a part of the Australian community.

An organization representing Cardinal Mooney High School minority graduates is calling a classroom lesson purportedly aimed at recreating the experience of slavery, deeply troubling.
The Cardinal Mooney High School Minority Alumni Council has issued a statement saying that a Black History lesson subject
continuation:
ing students to a "slavery simulation" was "deeply troubling."
In a letter to the school's principal and superintendent, members of the council said they were disturbed by what they described as an "inappropriate" and "disturbing" classroom activity.
According to the letter, which was obtained by The Philadelphia Inquirer and published on its website, a teacher in the social studies department presented the class with a PowerPoint presentation titled, "How Slavery Affected African-Americans," which included photographs of enslaved people and their captors.
Students were then asked to write about how slavery affected them. One student wrote that he had never seen a photograph of his great-great-grandparents before.
"I felt like I was seeing my ancestors for the first time," the student wrote. "I couldn't help but feel a sense of dread and sadness."
Members of the minority alumni council called the lesson "deeply troubling" and said it should be removed from the curriculum.
"We are concerned that this type of teaching will continue to perpetuate the idea that black lives don't matter," the letter reads. "This type of teaching perpetuates the idea that black lives don't matter. We cannot allow
paraphrase: The Cardinal Mooney High School Minority Alumni Council has expressed concerns over a recent classroom lesson that purportedly aimed to recreate the experience of slavery, deeming it "deeply troubling." In a letter to the school's principal and superintendent, members of the council highlighted their discontent with the lesson, which included a PowerPoint presentation featuring photographs of enslaved people and their captors, followed by a writing assignment that asked students to reflect on how slavery affected them. One student's response, in particular, stood out, as they wrote about feeling a sense of dread and sadness upon seeing photographs of their great-great-grandparents for the first time. The council members argue that this type of teaching can perpetuate the harmful notion that black lives don't matter and urged the school to remove the lesson from the curriculum.

continuation:
died, has just revealed.

In an exclusive interview with The Independent, Vladimir Ilyich Lenins great-grandson, Vladimir Ilyich Ulyanov (VILU), said: My grandfather was murdered in Mexico City on February 23rd, 1937. He was shot at point-blank range in front of my mother and two sisters. My grandmother was also killed, but she survived.

Lenin had been living in Mexico City with his second wife and their three children, including VILUs father, Mikhail Ilyich Ulyanov (MILU).

His death came just days after he had returned to Moscow from a trip to Cuba, where he had visited Fidel Castro and other leaders of the Cuban Revolution.

I think its important that people know what happened, VILU told The Independent. The truth is that my grandfather was assassinated because he stood up for workers rights and against Stalinism.

paraphrase:
Vladimir Lenin's great-grandson, Vladimir Ilyich Ulyanov (VILU), recently revealed that Lenin was murdered in Mexico City on February 23rd, 1937, at the age of 75, after being hunted down by Stalinist assassins. Lenin had been living in Mexico City with his second wife and their three children, including VILU's father, Mikhail Ilyich Ulyanov (MILU). His death came just days after he returned from a trip to Cuba, where he met with Fidel Castro and other leaders of the Cuban Revolution.
VILU believes it's crucial for people to know the truth about Lenin's assassination, which was motivated by his unwavering support for workers' rights and his opposition to Stalinism. ASHEVILLE  State Attorney General Josh Stein said Tuesday he wants to see changes in the proposed sale of Mission Health to HCA Healthcare
continuation:
, which is seeking approval from the North Carolina Board of Medicine.

We want to make sure that were doing everything we can to protect the interests of the patients who are going to be affected by this transaction, Stein said. Thats why I think its so important for us to look at how were going to do that.
Stein declined to comment further on the matter, citing ongoing negotiations between his office and HCA. He did not say whether his office would seek to block the deal if it goes through.
HCA has agreed to pay $2.4 billion to acquire Mission, one of the largest health care systems in the country. The deal is expected to close in the first half of 2020.

Im very concerned about the impact that this transaction could have on our Medicaid system, Stein said. Its something that Ive been working very hard on

How secure is your data on WhatsApp? Well, we answer all the top questions related to your privacy on the worlds most popular messaging application.
Last year, Facebook-owned WhatsApp rolled out end-to-end encryption for more than
continuation:
1 billion users in India. This means that only the sender and receiver of a message will be able to see each others messages.
WhatsApp has been under intense scrutiny over the last few years, especially after it was revealed that the company had shared user data with Cambridge Analytica during the 2016 US presidential elections.
The social media giant has also faced criticism for not doing enough to protect user data from being accessed by third-parties.
Here are some important things you need to know about WhatsApp:
1. What is end-to-end encryption?
End-to-end encryption (or E2EE) is a method of communication that allows two or more parties to communicate securely without revealing any information about one another.
In simple terms, it prevents anyone else from reading your messages unless you choose to share them.
2. How does WhatsApp use end-to-end encryption?
WhatsApp uses end-to-end encryption to ensure that no third party can read your messages.
To enable this feature, you will have to download the latest version of the app from the Play Store or App Store.
Once you do so, you will be asked to enter your phone number
paraphrase:
WhatsApp's data security: A comprehensive overview
WhatsApp, the world's most popular messaging application, has been under scrutiny for its data security measures. Last year, the Facebook-owned company rolled out end-to-end encryption for over 1 billion users in India, ensuring that only the sender and receiver of a message can view each other's communications. However, WhatsApp has faced criticism for its handling of user data, including sharing user information with Cambridge Analytica during the 2016 US presidential elections.
To address these concerns, here are some key things to know about WhatsApp's data security:
1. End-to-end encryption (E2EE): E2EE is a secure method of communication that allows two parties to communicate without revealing any information about each other. WhatsApp utilizes E2EE to protect user messages, making it difficult for anyone else to read them unless the sender or recipient chooses to share them.
2. How WhatsApp uses end-to-end encryption: To enable E2EE on WhatsApp, users must download the latest app version from the Play Store or App Store and enter their phone number. This feature ensures that no third party can access user messages.
By understanding how WhatsApp protects its users' data, you can rest assured that your messages are secure and private. However, it is essential to stay informed about any updates or changes to the platform's security measures to maintain the utmost protection for your personal information.

input:
Chelsea stand one win away from the Premier League title after mounting an impressive comeback to beat Leicester City at the King Power Stadium.
Jose Mourinho's side needed to call on all their reserves of quality and resilience to overcome Leicester City's fiercely determined challenge which
continuation:
saw them take a 2-0 lead into half-time thanks to goals from N'Golo Kante and Alvaro Morata.
Mourinho's men, who had lost just once in the league this season prior to kick-off, came out with renewed vigour in the second period and levelled through Eden Hazard before Marcos Alonso scored a late winner.
The result means that Chelsea are now only four points behind leaders Manchester United, who have a game in hand, and will be crowned champions if they can avoid defeat against Crystal Palace at Old Trafford on Sunday.
"It was a fantastic performance," Mourinho told Sky Sports. "I'm very proud of my team. I'm very proud of my players.
"We knew it was going to be difficult. We knew we were going to have to fight for every single ball."
Leicester manager Claude Puel said: "We played well in the first half, we created some good chances but we didn't score.
"In the second half we were much better, we controlled the game and we could have scored more than two goals.
"I am really disappointed because I think we should have been three or four goals up at half-time.
paraphrase:
Chelsea are just one victory away from clinching the Premier League title after an incredible comeback against Leicester City at the King Power Stadium.
Jose Mourinho's side displayed a remarkable display of quality and resilience to overcome Leicester City's fierce challenge, which saw them take a 2-0 lead into halftime courtesy of goals from N'Golo Kante and Alvaro Morata.
Determined to turn the game around, Mourinho's men emerged with renewed vigor in the second half and found the equalizer through Eden Hazard before Marcos Alonso scored the decisive goal.
The result means that Chelsea are now just four points behind league leaders Manchester United, who have a game in hand, and will be crowned champions if they can avoid defeat against Crystal Palace at Old Trafford on Sunday.
"It was an outstanding performance," Mourinho told Sky Sports. "I am incredibly proud of my team. I am incredibly proud of my players.
"We knew it was going to be a tough contest. We knew we would have to fight for every ball."
Leicester manager Claude Puel admitted: "We played well in the first half, creating some good chances but failing to score.
"In the second half, we improved and controlled the game, and could have scored more than two goals."
Puel was left disappointed as his side were unable to capitalize on their first-half dominance, feeling they should have been leading by more than two goals at halftime.

input: In the coming days, much of the coverage of the Chernobyl disaster in Russia is likely to focus on the 30-year anniversary and commemorations of it. The same may be said of reporting in Ukraine and Belarus, countries directly affected by the ramifications
continuation:
of the nuclear accident.

But there are other aspects of the disaster that deserve attention as well. For instance, a new report from the Institute for Science and International Security (ISIS), a think tank affiliated with the U.S. National Academies of Sciences, Engineering, and Medicine, has found that the Soviet Unions nuclear weapons program was far more extensive than previously thought.

The report, titled Soviet Nuclear Weapons: A Global Perspective, finds that the Soviet Union conducted at least 1,200 nuclear tests between 1945 and 1991. In addition, ISIS estimates that the Soviet Union had about 2,000 nuclear warheads during the Cold War, which would have been enough to destroy all of Europe.

Its important to note that these figures do not include tests conducted by the United States or its allies, such as Israel, Pakistan, and North Korea. And they dont take into account tests conducted by non-nuclear states, such as India, China, Pakistan, and North Korea.

Dodson added: "We are always looking for ways to grow our game across the globe and we believe this investment will further strengthen our position as a leading force in global rugby."

G

uterres told a news conference in New York that he had spoken with US President Donald Trump on Monday and urged him to reconsider his decision to slash $1.2 billion from the UN's annual budget for next year.
The United States is the largest contributor to the UN, contributing more than 20 percent of its total budget.
Trump's administration has proposed slashing $6.7 billion from the UN's $5.8 billion budget for 2018.
The United States contributes about $3.4 billion per year to the UN's peacekeeping operations, which have been hit hard by the Syrian civil war and other conflicts in recent years.
"We are going to try to convince the American people that this is not the right thing to do," Guterres said when asked if he would be able to persuade Trump to change his mind.
"I think it's very important that we don't give up on the idea of multilateralism. I think it's very important that we don't give up on the idea of global cooperation."

A senior State Department official told reporters at the same news conference that the administration was

input:
A Dayton jury found a state lawmaker not guilty of assault Tuesday.
DAYTON, TN (WRCB) -- A Dayton jury found a state lawmaker not guilty of assault Tuesday.
The assault trial for State Rep. Jim Cobb opened Tuesday morning
continuation:
in the Montgomery County Courthouse.
Cobb was accused of punching and kicking his ex-wife during an argument at their home back in October of 2015.
Prosecutors said Cobb hit her in the face with a closed fist and kicked her in the groin area.
Cobb's attorney told jurors the incident happened after he got into an argument with his wife.
"I'm going to make it clear that I don't think this case is about me," Cobb said. "It's about my family. It's about my children. It's about my wife. And it's about my children's future."
During closing arguments, Cobb's attorney argued there was no physical evidence to support the charges against his client.
"He didn't do anything wrong. He did nothing more than what any father would do if they were involved in a domestic dispute," Cobb's attorney said.
Cobb will be released from jail on a $5,000 bond.
His next court date is scheduled for April 24.
Stay with WRCBtv.com for updates on this developing story.

The trial began Tuesday morning at the Montgomery County Courthouse, with Cobb facing charges of punching and kicking his ex-wife during an argument at their home in October 2015. Prosecutors claimed that Cobb hit his wife in the face with a closed fist and kicked her in the groin area. However, Cobb's attorney argued that the incident occurred after he became embroiled in an argument with his wife, and maintained that his client did nothing wrong. The attorney stated that there was no physical evidence to support the charges against Cobb. After the trial, Cobb was released from jail on a $5,000 bond, and his next court date is scheduled for April 24. Stay tuned to WRCBtv.com for updates on this developing story.

continuation:
Peace and Reconciliation in Darfur (DPRD).

In a statement released on Tuesday, the SPLM-AW said it was concerned about the unilateral decision of the United States to withdraw from the Doha Document for Peace and Reconciliation in Darfur (DPRD).

The unilateral decision of the United States to withdraw from the Doha Document for Peace and Reconciliation in Darfur (DPRD) is not in line with the spirit of the agreement between the two countries, the statement said.

It pointed out that the withdrawal of the U.S. from the document will have negative effects on the peace process in the country.

The SPLM-AW also called on the international community to take measures to protect the interests of the Sudanese people as well as their right to self-determination.

On Monday, the U.S. Department of State announced that Washington had decided to withdraw from the Doha Document for Peace and Reconciliation in Darfur (DPRD) because it does not meet the conditions set by the U.S. government.

A spokesman for the U.S. Embassy in Kh
paraphrase: The rebel Sudan Liberation Movement led by Abdel Wahid Al-Nur (SPLM-AW) has urged the US administration to reconsider its decision to withdraw from the Doha Document for Peace and Reconciliation in Darfur (DPRD). In a statement released on Tuesday, the SPLM-AW expressed concerns that the US withdrawal goes against the spirit of the agreement between the two countries and may have negative consequences for the peace process in Sudan. The group also called on the international community to take measures to protect the interests of the Sudanese people and their right to self-determination. On Monday, the US Department of State announced that Washington had decided to withdraw from the DPRD due to the document's failure to meet US government conditions. A spokesperson for the US Embassy in Khartoum further clarified that the US decision was made in response to the lack of progress in the peace negotiations and the failure of the DPRD to address the root causes of the conflict in Darfur.

input: IN WRITING about the year gone by, the first thing that strikes one is that this was the year of the spare cash. Almost all people in the middle class seemed to have extra money to spend. In many cases it was borrowed money but
continuation:
there were also those who had saved up for a long time and spent it on luxuries such as cars or holidays abroad.

One of the most popular purchases was a new mobile phone. A survey carried out by Vodafone found that more than two-thirds (68 per cent) of adults aged 18-24 said they would be willing to pay an extra 10 a month to get their hands on a new handset. Thats almost double the average price of a new phone at the end of last year (6.99), which was 4.99.

There are several reasons why this has happened. The first is that the market has become so competitive that consumers are looking for the best value for money. The second reason is that phones are getting better and better, with features such as video calling and 3G connectivity becoming increasingly important. And thirdly, there is a growing demand for high-end devices from brands such as Apple, Samsung and Sony.

But what about the rest of us? How do we make sure we dont fall into the trap of spending too much? Here are a few tips to help you keep your finances under control.

1. Keep track
paraphrase:
Reflecting on the recent past, one notable aspect stands out - the prevalence of excess cash. The middle class appeared to have an abundance of disposable income, with many relying on borrowed funds or saved up savings to indulge in luxuries such as cars, vacations, or high-end electronics.
A Vodafone survey found that over two-thirds (68%) of adults aged 18-24 were willing to pay an extra 10 dollars per month for a new mobile phone, indicating the growing demand for cutting-edge devices with innovative features like video calling and 3G connectivity.

To avoid overspending, consider these tips to manage your finances effectively:

1. Maintain a thorough financial record to monitor your expenses and prevent uncontrolled spending.


In conclusion, while the abundance of disposable income in the middle class presents opportunities for luxurious purchases, it is crucial to remain mindful of one's financial situation to avoid falling into the trap of excessive spending.

input:
Great Britain have finished outside the medals at the World Wheelchair Rugby Championships in Canada.
However, their sixth-placed finish sees GB, who were ranked ninth in the world before the tournament, move three places up the world rankings.
Captain Steve
continuation:
Cram said: "It's been a tough tournament for us, but we've still come away with a lot of positives to take from it.
"We're looking forward to next year's Commonwealth Games in Australia and I'm sure that will be a great experience for everyone involved."
The GB squad was made up of eight men and four women.
They started their campaign on Friday evening when they played host nation Canada in an opening pool match.
GB went down 19-12 after being reduced to 14 men in the first half.
On Saturday, they faced New Zealand in a quarter-final match which they won 21-7.
In Sunday's semi-finals, GB beat South Africa 17-10 to set up a final against the United States on Monday night.
Cram added: "I'm really proud of the way our team has performed over the last couple of days.
"We've got a lot of young players coming through so it's great to see them getting some game time under their belt.
"We'll go back to the drawing board now and focus on what we can do better in the future.
"We want to keep progressing as a team and hopefully get to the Commonwealth Games
paraphrase: Great Britain's journey at the World Wheelchair Rugby Championships in Canada ended without a medal, but they still managed to make significant strides in the world rankings. Despite being ranked ninth before the tournament, they climbed three spots to sixth place after their sixth-placed finish. Captain Steve Cram expressed his team's mixed feelings, stating, "It's been a challenging event for us, but we're taking plenty of positives back with us. We're excited for the Commonwealth Games in Australia next year and I'm sure it will be a great experience for everyone involved." The GB squad consisted of eight men and four women, who began their campaign on Friday evening with an opening pool match against Canada. Despite being reduced to 14 men in the first half, they fought hard and won their quarter-final match against New Zealand on Saturday. They went on to beat South Africa in the semi-finals on Sunday and faced off against the United States in the final on Monday night. Cram praised his team's performance, saying, "I'm extremely proud of how our team has performed over the past few days. We have a lot of young players coming through, and it's great to see them gaining valuable game experience. We'll review our performance and work on improving for the future."

paraphrase:

input: And this is what happens when you take people from outside of tech, in this case Michael Pachter, an analyst at Wedbush Securities (based in LA), and collide them with topics that they dont understand, in this case,
continuation:
video games.

The result is a series of interviews with some of the biggest names in the gaming industry about their thoughts on the future of the industry. Its interesting to see how different perspectives can be brought to bear on the same topic.

Im not going to go into too much detail here, but I will say that it seems as though there are a few common themes:

1) The console wars are over.

2) Gamers are becoming less interested in single-player games and more interested in multiplayer games.

3) The mobile market is the next big opportunity for game developers.

4) The PC market is still the best place to make money.

5) Game development is a lot more expensive now than it was 20 years ago.

6) There are a lot of companies that have been around for a long time that havent been able to adapt to changing consumer tastes.

7) And finally, theres a new generation of gamers coming into the market.

Its worth noting that none of these things are bad things. In fact, they all sound like great things.

But
paraphrase:
After bringing in an outsider, Michael Pachter, an analyst at Wedbush Securities, to discuss the future of the gaming industry, a fascinating series of interviews with key figures in the industry emerged. It was intriguing to observe how diverse perspectives could be applied to the same topic.

The main themes that arose during these interviews were:

1. The console wars have ended, and a new era of gaming has begun.

2. Gamers are shifting their focus from single-player games to multiplayer experiences.

3. The mobile market presents a significant opportunity for game developers.

4. The PC market continues to be the most lucrative for game developers.

5. Game development has become more expensive over the past 20 years, requiring more resources and expertise.

6. Many long-standing game developers are struggling to adapt to changing consumer preferences.

7. Finally, a new generation of gamers is entering the market with fresh ideas and enthusiasm.

While these trends are not necessarily negative, they all point to an exciting and transformative time for the gaming industry.

. He told me that he wanted to become an engineer.

Engineering is not for everyone, he said. There are many people who want to become engineers but dont know what they want to do with their lives.

He went on to tell me that he didnt want to be a teacher or a doctor because he felt that these professions were more important than engineering.

paraphrase:
Twenty-five years on, I had the pleasure of speaking with a young man who was struggling to find direction in his life. I asked him a simple question, and he began to open up about his aspirations. I was impressed by his ambition, and he revealed that he desired to become an engineer.
Engineering is not a career path for everyone, he said, explaining that many individuals desire to pursue engineering but lack clarity about their life goals.
He went on to share that he didn't wish to follow the path of teaching or medicine, as he believed these professions were more critical than engineering.
I was taken aback by his statement, as engineering has always been a fascinating subject in my school years. In fact, I became so passionate about it that upon graduating from high school, I decided to study engineering at the University of California, Los Angeles (UCLA).
When I first arrived at UCLA, I was uncertain about what to expect. After all, I had never heard of engineering before. However, I soon discovered that there were thousands of engineering students across the country who were in a similar situation.
According to the U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics (BLS), the number of engineering graduates in the United States has been steadily increasing every year since the mid-1990s. The BLS predicts that there will be over 1 million engineering jobs available in the country by 2025.

DEFIANT Alan Shearer has urged his relegation-haunted Newcastle side to keep the faith.
With just one point from three games since he returned to St Jamess Park, the Geordie icon has been unable to work an
continuation:
escape route for Steve Bruces men.
The Magpies have now lost five of their last six Premier League games and are bottom of the table with only four points from a possible 18.
And former England captain Shearer believes it is vital that the club do not give up on the season.
He told talkSPORT: Im not sure how long this can go on but I think its time to start thinking about next year.
Weve got a lot of young players coming through and they need to be given the chance to prove themselves.
If you look at the likes of Dwight Gayle, Allan Saint-Maximin, Callum Wilson, Joelinton, Miguel Almiron  all these young lads are going to get better and better as they play more games.
I dont know whats going on behind the scenes but its not good enough at the moment.
Id like to see the fans back in the stadium as soon as possible.
It would be great if we could get them back into the stadium as soon as possible.
paraphrase:
Alan Shearer has urged his struggling Newcastle side to maintain their resolve despite their poor run of form.
With only one point from three games since his return to St. James' Park, Shearer has been unable to turn things around for Steve Bruce's men. The Magpies have now lost five of their last six Premier League matches and find themselves bottom of the table with only four points from a possible 18.
Former England captain Shearer believes it is crucial that the club does not give up on the season, highlighting the potential of their young players. He told talkSPORT: "I think it's time to start thinking about next year. We've got a lot of young talent coming through and they need to be given the chance to prove themselves."

Despite the team's struggles, Shearer emphasized the importance of the fans' support, stating, "I'd like to see the fans back in the stadium as soon as possible. It would be great if we could get them back in the stadium as soon as possible."

input: This years monster El Nio is truly a monsterits been blamed for killing coral reefs. Add another die-off to the list: Southern California beaches are blanketed in hundreds of thousands of tiny crabs. So many that
continuation:
theyre clogging the sand and making it hard for surfers to catch waves.

The crabs, which can be up to 10 inches long and weigh as much as a pound, have been washing up on the shorelines of Huntington Beach, San Clemente, Encinitas, Carlsbad, and La Jolla since last week.

Weve never seen anything like this before, said Chris Hahn, an oceanographer with the U.S. Geological Survey (USGS) whos been tracking the crabs for the past two years. Its not just a few thousand here and there; were talking about hundreds of thousands.

Hahn says hes not sure whats causing the mass die-off, but he suspects it has something to do with climate change.

I dont know if its a natural phenomenon or if its caused by global warming, he said. But whatever it is, I think its going to get worse.

According to the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (
paraphrase:
This year's powerful El Nio event has led to yet another marine mass mortality incident, with Southern California beaches blanketed in an unprecedented number of tiny crabs. The crabs, which can grow up to 10 inches in length and weigh as much as a pound, have been washing up on the shorelines of Huntington Beach, San Clemente, Encinitas, Carlsbad, and La Jolla since last week.
While this phenomenon has never been observed before, oceanographers with the U.S. Geological Survey (USGS) suspect that climate change may be the cause. "I don't know if it's a natural phenomenon or if it's caused by global warming," said Chris Hahn, an USGS oceanographer who has been tracking the crabs for the past two years. "But whatever it is, I think it's going to get worse."
According to the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA), the mass die-off has been attributed to a combination of factors, including warming ocean temperatures and changes in ocean currents. While the exact cause of the mass mortality remains unclear, scientists are working to better understand the complex interactions between climate and marine ecosystems.

input:
Thousands of people march in Istanbul and around the world over raid on Gaza convoy.
Palestinians in the occupied West Bank clashed with Israeli security forces who responded with tear gas, injuring many people.
An emergency session of the United Nations Security Council
continuation:
has been called for Friday to discuss the latest violence between Israel and the Palestinians.
The UN's Middle East envoy Nickolay Mladenov will brief the 15-member body at 11am (09:00 GMT).
The meeting is expected to be dominated by a call for an immediate cease-fire between Israel and the Palestinian militant group Hamas, which controls the Gaza Strip.
Israel has carried out hundreds of air strikes in Gaza since it began its offensive on Monday.
At least 139 Palestinians have been killed, including 59 children and 36 women, according to the Gaza health ministry.
Hamas has fired more than 4,000 rockets into Israel since the fighting broke out, while Israeli aircraft have struck dozens of targets belonging to Hamas and other militant groups.
More than 2,700 Palestinians have been wounded in the Israeli bombardment of Gaza.
UN Secretary-General Antnio Guterres said on Thursday that he was deeply concerned about the escalation of violence in the region.
"I strongly urge all parties to exercise maximum restraint and avoid any actions that could lead to further loss of life and damage to property," he told reporters in New York.
He added that he was "deeply disturbed" by reports of civilian casualties
paraphrase:
Thousands of protesters marched in Istanbul and across the globe in solidarity with the besieged Gaza Strip, denouncing the recent raid on a Gaza-bound aid convoy.
In the occupied West Bank, Palestinians clashed with Israeli security forces, resulting in injuries to many.
In response, the United Nations Security Council has called for an emergency meeting on Friday, where the UN's Middle East envoy Nickolay Mladenov will brief the 15-member body at 11am (09:00 GMT).
The meeting is expected to focus on urgent calls for an immediate ceasefire between Israel and the Hamas-led Palestinian militant group, following Israel's launch of hundreds of airstrikes in Gaza since Monday.
According to the Gaza health ministry, at least 139 Palestinians have been killed, including 59 children and 36 women, while Hamas has fired over 4,000 rockets into Israel. Israeli aircraft have struck dozens of targets belonging to Hamas and other militant groups, leaving over 2,700 Palestinians wounded in the Israeli bombardment.
UN Secretary-General Antnio Guterres expressed deep concern over the escalating violence in the region, urging all parties to exercise maximum restraint and avoid any actions leading to further loss of life and property. He was particularly disturbed by reports of civilian casualties.

input: If you are willing to take the time to calculate the needed calories to bulk up, the process should be relatively simple. Bulking up or building muscle means getting a mass stimulus from resistance-training and then supplying your body with adequate
continuation:
amounts of energy through food.

The problem is that most people dont know what they need to do in order to achieve their goals. So, how do we get started?

Calculating Your Calorie Needs

First, lets look at some basic numbers:

Weight (kg)

Body Mass Index (BMI)

Age (years)

Height (inches)

Weight (lbs)

Calories Per Day (kcal/day)

Total Fat (g)

Carbohydrates (g)

Dietary Fiber (g)

Sugars (g)

Protein (g)

Vitamin B12 (mcg)

Iron (mg)

Calcium (mg)

Magnesium (mg)

Folate (mcg)

Zinc (mg)

Potassium (mg)

How Much Should You Eat?

To calculate your daily calorie needs, divide your weight in kilograms by your height in inches. For example, if you weigh 150 pounds and have a BMI of 25, you will require about 2,500 calories
paraphrase:
To determine your daily calorie needs for muscle growth, a straightforward approach involves calculating your basal metabolic rate (BMR) based on your weight, age, height, and gender. Then, you can factor in an energy surplus to account for the additional calories required for muscle growth.
Let's begin by examining some fundamental metrics:
Weight (kg)

Body Mass Index (BMI)

Age (years)

Height (inches)

Weight (lbs)

Calories Per Day (kcal/day)

Total Fat (g)

Carbohydrates (g)

Dietary Fiber (g)

Sugars (g)

Protein (g)

Vitamin B12 (mcg)

Iron (mg)

Calcium (mg)

Magnesium (mg)

Folate (mcg)

Zinc (mg)

Potassium (mg)

Now, let's calculate your daily calorie needs: divide your weight in kilograms by your height in inches. For instance, if you weigh 150 pounds and have a BMI of 25, you will require around 2,500 calories.
However, this is just your basal metabolic rate, and you'll need to consume additional calories to support muscle growth. A general rule of thumb is to consume an additional 250-500 calories per day above your BMR to promote muscle growth.
So, in this example, you would aim for approximately 2,750-3,000 calories per day to support muscle growth.
Remember, these are general guidelines, and your individual calorie needs may vary depending on your specific goals and circumstances. It's always a good idea to consult with a healthcare professional or registered dietitian to determine the best calorie intake for your unique needs.

input:
Airlift of a Marine Corps battalion to Lebanon demonstrated that deploying contingency forces from the continental United States to an overseas operation was feasible and expeditious.
During the Cold War, the United States deployed its Armed Forces to support the national objectives of various
continuation:
countries in the Middle East and Central Asia. The U.S. Air Force was responsible for the airlift of troops and materiel from the continental United States to combat zones throughout the world.
In the early 1990s, President George H.W. Bush directed the Department of Defense (DoD) to develop plans to provide airlift capabilities to the United Nations Command (UNOCOM) in Beirut, Lebanon, as part of Operation Desert Shield/Desert Storm. In order to achieve this objective, the DoD established the Joint Military Airlift Task Force (JMATF), which was charged with planning and executing airlift operations for contingencies such as those occurring in the Persian Gulf region during the 1991 Gulf War. The JMATF's mission was to ensure that the U.S. military had the capability to rapidly transport personnel, equipment, supplies, and other necessary materials into and out of the country in the event of an armed conflict.
To accomplish this task, the JMATF developed a plan to deploy a Marine Corps aviation battalion from Camp Lejeune, N.C., to Beirut, Lebanon, on a rotational basis. The battalion would be supported by two C-17 Globemaster III cargo aircraft
paraphrase:
The deployment of a Marine Corps battalion to Lebanon demonstrated the feasibility and efficiency of deploying contingency forces from the United States to support military operations overseas. During the Cold War, the US military deployed its forces to various countries in the Middle East and Central Asia to support national objectives. The US Air Force was responsible for airlifting troops and equipment from the continental United States to combat zones around the world.
In the early 1990s, President George H.W. Bush directed the DoD to develop plans to provide airlift capabilities to the United Nations Command in Beirut, Lebanon, as part of Operation Desert Shield/Desert Storm. To achieve this goal, the DoD established the Joint Military Airlift Task Force, which was responsible for planning and executing airlift operations for contingencies in the Persian Gulf region. The JMATF's mission was to ensure the US military had the capability to rapidly transport personnel, equipment, supplies, and other materials into and out of the country in the event of an armed conflict.
To accomplish this, the JMATF developed a plan to deploy a Marine Corps aviation battalion from Camp Lejeune, North Carolina, to Beirut, Lebanon, on a rotational basis. The battalion would be supported by two C-17 Globemaster III cargo aircraft.

input: People and Us Weekly editors are in heaven: Both Jennifer Aniston and hubby Brad Pitt snagged Emmy noms Thursday. Aniston snagged a comedy best actress nod for having a baby on Friends; Pitt scored for a guest
continuation:
-starring role on HBOs Boardwalk Empire.

Aniston, 51, is up against the likes of Julia Louis-Dreyfus, Meryl Streep, Sandra Bullock and Amy Adams for her role as Phoebe Buffay on the NBC sitcom, which ran from 1994 to 2004.

Pitt, 56, nabbed a supporting actor nomination for his role as mobster Frank Sheeran in HBOs Boardwalk Empire. He also starred in The Assassination of Jesse James by the Coward Robert Ford with Leonardo DiCaprio and Margot Robbie earlier this year.

Aniston has been nominated three times before for the award, but never won. She previously took home the trophy in 1998 for playing Rachel Green on the first two seasons of Friends. She was nominated again in 2003 for her role in The Morning Show alongside Reese Witherspoon and Steve Carell.

Pitt, meanwhile, has yet to win any Emmys. In fact, hes only been nominated once
paraphrase: The entertainment industry is abuzz with excitement as both Jennifer Aniston and her husband Brad Pitt have received Emmy nominations. Aniston, a seasoned actress known for her roles on Friends and The Morning Show, has been nominated for Best Comedic Actress for her portrayal of Phoebe Buffay on the popular sitcom. Pitt, a talented actor with a diverse range of roles under his belt, has scored a nomination for his guest appearance on HBO's Boardwalk Empire. This marks Aniston's third Emmy nomination, but she has yet to take home the trophy. Meanwhile, Pitt has only been nominated once before, highlighting his growing recognition in the industry. Both Aniston and Pitt are well-known for their impressive acting chops, and their nominations are a testament to their dedication and skill.

input:
A British entrepreneur 'committed a deliberate fraud over a sustained period of time' to artificially inflate the value of his software company by billions of dollars ahead of its sale, the High Court has heard.
Hewlett-Packard (HP
continuation:
) founder and former chief executive Meg Whitman is accused of concealing from investors that the company was losing money in an effort to inflate its share price.
She is also alleged to have made false statements about the company's financial condition when she announced her resignation as CEO in January 2015.
Ms Whitman denies any wrongdoing.
The case is due to resume on Tuesday.
In a written statement, Ms Whitman said: "I categorically deny the allegations against me and look forward to clearing my name at trial."
Her lawyers told the court that they were confident their client would be found not guilty.
"We are confident that our client will be vindicated in this matter," they said.
Image copyright Getty Images Image caption Hewlett-Packard sold its PC business to Lenovo for $11.1bn (8.7bn) in 2016
Ms Whitman founded HP in 1981 with her then husband Mark Hurd, who died in 2013.
It was one of the first computer companies to go public in the 1980s and went on to become the world's second-largest personal computer maker behind IBM.
But it was hit hard by the rise of tablets and smartphones, and in 2014 it agreed to be bought out by
paraphrase: A British entrepreneur allegedly perpetrated a deliberate fraud over a prolonged period, inflating the value of their software company by billions of dollars prior to its sale, the High Court has heard. Meg Whitman, the founder and former CEO of Hewlett-Packard (HP), is accused of concealing the company's financial losses from investors to artificially boost its share price. Whitman has denied any wrongdoing, stating that she looks forward to clearing her name at trial in a written statement. Her legal representatives expressed confidence that their client would be found not guilty, claiming they were confident that their client would be vindicated in this matter. Whitman founded HP in 1981 alongside her late husband Mark Hurd, who passed away in 2013. At the time, it was one of the first computer companies to go public in the 1980s and went on to become the world's second-largest personal computer maker behind IBM. However, the company was significantly impacted by the rise of tablets and smartphones, and in 2014 it agreed to be acquired by another company.

group that represents more than 1,000 small and medium-sized businesses, has vowed to continue its legal challenge of the bill, which was passed by the House of Commons last week and now awaits royal assent from Queen Elizabeth II before it can become law.
Were not going to stop until we get what we believe is fair taxation, said David MacNaughton, executive director of CFSBTF. Weve been fighting this battle for almost two years. Its time for the government to listen to the people who are paying their taxes.

Im not going to pre-empt any of the work thats going
paraphrase:
The fight against Ottawa's proposed tax reforms for small enterprises is ongoing, even after watered-down policies were included in the latest federal budget following months of business community resistance.
The Coalition for Small Business Tax Fairness, a collective of over 1,000 small and medium-sized businesses, has vowed to continue legal action against the bill, which was passed by the House of Commons last week and now awaits royal assent from Queen Elizabeth II before becoming law.
"We won't stop until we get fair taxation," said David MacNaughton, executive director of CFSBTF. "We've been fighting this battle for almost two years. It's time for the government to listen to the people who are paying their taxes."
MacNaughton expressed optimism about the possibility of new measures being introduced by Prime Minister Justin Trudeau and Finance Minister Bill Morneau to aid small businesses affected by the tax changes.
As Morneau told The Canadian Press in an interview earlier this month, "I will look at ways to reduce the tax burden on small businesses," although he did not provide specifics.
While Morneau did not provide details on the potential new measures, he left the door open for future action to alleviate the tax burden on small businesses.
